oai_dc:dc.dc:description: embracing the tortoise, the little hare, and the old woman, in the Katkop dialect (by Dia!kw in, who had it from his mother #k mme an), written by L (B XXVI. 2487 2529, XXVII. 2530 2535). It ends with the mother s advice to Dia!kw in, as a moral to the fable (B XXVII. 2535_2539). [The account of The Lions, the Tortoise, the little Hare and the old Woman], Dia!kwain's mother tells him to pick up and take home a male tortoise if he sees one. The people worry that if they eat a tortoise it will avenge itself upon them, as it did with the lion who starved to death on account of his bad luck with finding food. But Dia!kwain's mother says that the tortoise will not take revenge if it understands that the person eating it is hungry and so a hunter must take it even if the tortoise doesn't want him to.
oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The advice that Dia!kwain's mother gave him about the tortoise, i.e. that he must not leave one, if he saw it, but must take it home
